awd_titl_txt: CICI: CCoE: Trusted CI: Advancing Trustworthy Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation funds over seven billion dollars of research annually, nearly all of which relies heavily on information technology. The digital data produced and computing systems used by that research are subject to risks from cyber attacks, in some cases similar to other data and computing systems on the Internet and in other cases particular to their research mission. Cybersecurity appropriate to the research mission is necessary both to make today's scientific discoveries possible and to ensure that the science is trustworthy. Appropriate cybersecurity must respect the collaborative environments that span organizational and national boundaries, the high-performance technologies used to manage large scale data and computation, and the dynamic information technology demands common in NSF research. Different science domains also have varying requirements for data confidentiality, availability, and integrity. These aspects challenge the use of traditional cybersecurity paradigms and technologies to manage the risks to trustworthy, reproducible research.

As the NSF Cybersecurity Center of Excellence, Trusted CI brings together experts in cybersecurity, knowledgeable and experienced in the NSF research endeavor, who provide the NSF community with the leadership and support necessary to tackle the cybersecurity challenges to NSF research. Trusted CI directly supports individual NSF cyberinfrastructure projects and Major Facilities through collaborative engagements that address specific project needs. Trusted CI engagement activities include (but are not limited to) security reviews, security architecture design, identity and access management, and software assurance. Trusted CI provides cybersecurity situational awareness to the NSF cyberinfrastructure community through timely advisories and notices. Trusted CI organizes the annual NSF Cybersecurity Summit for Large Facilities and Cyberinfrastructure, providing the community with the opportunity to share lessons learned, attend practical training sessions, and collaborate on solving common challenges. Trusted CI performs outreach and dissemination of best practices via the Trusted CI website (http://trustedci.org), blog posts, email lists, and online chats, as well as providing cybersecurity training in person and via online courses. Leadership activities of Trusted CI include developing a cybersecurity framework for NSF science and fostering the transition to practice of NSF cybersecurity research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report

Trusted CI: The NSF Cybersecurity Center of Excellence

NSF Grants ACI-1920430 and 2241313

October 1, 2019 - December 31, 2024

Team

Ishan Abhinit, Andrew Adams, Dan Arnold, Jim Basney (PI), Kathy Benninger, Diana Cimmer, Jeannette Dopheide, Josh Drake, Shane Filus, Terry Fleury, Dr. Elisa Heymann, Craig Jackson, Mikeal Jones, Mark Krenz, Devaki Kulkarni, Jim Marsteller (co-PI), Prof. Barton Miller (co-PI), Megha Moncy, Hawa Naaata, Drew Paine, Sean Peisert (co-PI), Ranson Ricks, Damian Rouson, Scott Russell, Kelli Shute (co-PI), Mike Simpson, John Zage

Project Outcomes

Under NSF grants 1920430 and 2241313, Trusted CI continued to provide the NSF CI community with cybersecurity leadership, expertise, training, and a forum for sharing cybersecurity experiences and lessons learned. These efforts improved the practice of cybersecurity across the ecosystem of NSF cyberinfrastructure projects and hence the trustworthiness of the NSF science. During this award period, Trusted CI built upon its prior experience, making significant progress toward a secure NSF CI community in which each project:

  • knows where it fits in a coherent cybersecurity ecosystem. 

  • has access to the tools and expertise to enact a cybersecurity program that efficiently supports their science mission.

  • participates in the sharing of experiences and collaboration between projects.

During the award period, Trusted CI directly engaged with forty-two NSF projects to aid them with their cybersecurity challenges. These challenges included establishment and review of cybersecurity programs and the design and evaluation of software security features. Trusted CI also planned and hosted the annual NSF Cybersecurity Summits bringing together hundreds of members of the NSF CI community each year to receive training, hear from experts from outside the community, build relationships, and share experiences. Over 1,454 individuals, representing over two hundred and sixty-two NSF projects, attended at least one of the five Trusted CI-hosted NSF Summits during the award period. Public reports from each of the Summits served to document its findings.

Additional outcomes from the award period include:

  • We released the Trusted CI Framework Implementation Guide for Research Cyberinfrastructure Operators. The guide has been downloaded more than 3,000 times since publication and has been extensively used to assist organizations in adopting and aligning to the Framework.

  • We facilitated five Framework cohorts, supporting 27 facilities and projects as they adopted the Framework.

  • We established the Research Infrastructure Security Community (RISC), a community of practice for NSF cybersecurity professionals. RISC is composed of graduates from the Trusted CI Framework Cohort Program. We facilitate quarterly workshops on cybersecurity program development and evolution, new tools and training, and other cybersecurity topics and experiences.

  • The Trusted CI webinar series hosted 49 talks with 2,506 total attendees across 248 NSF projects and over 5,149 views of the recorded presentations. Trusted CI has now impacted over 570 NSF projects through its webinars, engagements, and other activities.

  • We completed 19 direct engagements with NSF Major Facilities and other funded research projects.

  • The Cyberinfrastructure Vulnerabilities service alerted the community to 117 critical vulnerabilities after evaluating a total of 195.

  • We trained 36 Fellows, members of the scientific community, to empower them with basic knowledge of cybersecurity and the understanding of Trusted CI’s services. After their Fellows cohort experience concluded, they now serve as cybersecurity liaisons to their respective communities.

  • With guidance from the Advisory Committee, we established a set of new programmatic foci and realigned our activities to those foci. We established new activities, including the Framework Cohort (a group engagement focused on supporting Framework adoption and development of cybersecurity program strategic plans) and Ambassadors Program (which provides regular, direct contact between Trusted CI and each NSF Major Facility).

  • Beginning in 2022, our Annual Challenge team focused on operational technology / cyber physical systems. In the following years, the team published the Roadmap for Securing Operational Technology in NSF Scientific Research and the OT Procurement Vendor Matrix.

  • Beginning in 2022, Trusted CI team members attended the annual Research Infrastructure Workshop held by NSF. We delivered cybersecurity content relevant to multi-disciplinary staff and leadership at the Major Facilities (MFs). 

  • We supported the launch of the Minority Serving Cyberinfrastructure Consortium (MS-CC) Cybersecurity Community of Practice. Jim Basney (CoP co-chair), Sean Peisert, Damian Rouson, and Kelli Shute attended the monthly meetings, which are well attended by MS-CC member institutions.

  • We received confirmation from a prior engagee, the Academic Research Fleet, that they were able to secure additional funding as a result of our engagement report delivered in 2019.

All Trusted CI reports, guides, and training materials are publicly available at trustedci.org and are permanently archived via Zenodo according to the Trusted CI Data Management Plan.


Last Modified: 03/27/2025
Modified by: Kelli Shute

Outcomes Report


Trusted CI:The NSF Cybersecurity Center of Excellence


NSF Grants ACI-1920430 and 2241313


October 1, 2019 - December 31, 2024


Team


Ishan Abhinit,Andrew Adams,Dan Arnold,Jim Basney(PI), Kathy Benninger,Diana Cimmer,Jeannette Dopheide,Josh Drake,Shane Filus,Terry Fleury,Dr. Elisa Heymann,Craig Jackson,Mikeal Jones,Mark Krenz,Devaki Kulkarni,Jim Marsteller(co-PI), Prof. Barton Miller(co-PI), Megha Moncy,Hawa Naaata,Drew Paine,Sean Peisert(co-PI), Ranson Ricks,Damian Rouson,Scott Russell,Kelli Shute(co-PI), Mike Simpson,John Zage
Project Outcomes


Under NSF grants 1920430 and 2241313, Trusted CI continued to provide the NSF CI community with cybersecurity leadership, expertise, training, and a forum for sharing cybersecurity experiences and lessons learned. These efforts improved the practice of cybersecurity across the ecosystem of NSF cyberinfrastructure projects and hence the trustworthiness of the NSF science. During this award period, Trusted CI built upon its prior experience, making significant progress toward a secure NSF CI community in which each project:




knows where it fits in a coherent cybersecurity ecosystem.




has access to the tools and expertise to enact a cybersecurity program that efficiently supports their science mission.




participates in the sharing of experiences and collaboration between projects.




During the award period, Trusted CI directly engaged with forty-two NSF projects to aid them with their cybersecurity challenges. These challenges included establishment and review of cybersecurity programs and the design and evaluation of software security features. Trusted CI also planned and hosted the annual NSF Cybersecurity Summits bringing together hundreds of members of the NSF CI community each year to receive training, hear from experts from outside the community, build relationships, and share experiences. Over 1,454 individuals, representing over two hundred and sixty-two NSF projects, attended at least one of the five Trusted CI-hosted NSF Summits during the award period. Public reports from each of the Summits served to document its findings.


Additional outcomes from the award period include:




We released the Trusted CI Framework Implementation Guide for Research Cyberinfrastructure Operators. The guide has been downloaded more than 3,000 times since publication and has been extensively used to assist organizations in adopting and aligning to the Framework.




We facilitated five Framework cohorts, supporting 27 facilities and projects as they adopted the Framework.




We established the Research Infrastructure Security Community (RISC), a community of practice for NSF cybersecurity professionals. RISC is composed of graduates from the Trusted CI Framework Cohort Program. We facilitate quarterly workshops on cybersecurity program development and evolution, new tools and training, and other cybersecurity topics and experiences.




The Trusted CI webinar series hosted 49 talks with 2,506 total attendees across 248 NSF projects and over 5,149 views of the recorded presentations. Trusted CI has now impacted over 570 NSF projects through its webinars, engagements, and other activities.




We completed 19 direct engagements with NSF Major Facilities and other funded research projects.




The Cyberinfrastructure Vulnerabilities service alerted the community to 117 critical vulnerabilities after evaluating a total of 195.




We trained 36 Fellows, members of the scientific community, to empower them with basic knowledge of cybersecurity and the understanding of Trusted CIs services. After their Fellows cohort experience concluded, they now serve as cybersecurity liaisons to their respective communities.




With guidance from the Advisory Committee, we established a set of new programmatic foci and realigned our activities to those foci. We established new activities, including the Framework Cohort (a group engagement focused on supporting Framework adoption and development of cybersecurity program strategic plans) and Ambassadors Program (which provides regular, direct contact between Trusted CI and each NSF Major Facility).




Beginning in 2022, our Annual Challenge team focused on operational technology / cyber physical systems. In the following years, the team published the Roadmap for Securing Operational Technology in NSF Scientific Research and the OT Procurement Vendor Matrix.




Beginning in 2022, Trusted CI team members attended the annual Research Infrastructure Workshop held by NSF. We delivered cybersecurity content relevant to multi-disciplinary staff and leadership at the Major Facilities (MFs).




We supported the launch of the Minority Serving Cyberinfrastructure Consortium (MS-CC) Cybersecurity Community of Practice. Jim Basney (CoP co-chair), Sean Peisert, Damian Rouson, and Kelli Shute attended the monthly meetings, which are well attended by MS-CC member institutions.




We received confirmation from a prior engagee, the Academic Research Fleet, that they were able to secure additional funding as a result of our engagement report delivered in 2019.




All Trusted CI reports, guides, and training materials are publicly available at trustedci.org and are permanently archived via Zenodo according to the Trusted CI Data Management Plan.					Last Modified: 03/27/2025
